#Text=Tell if an Avocado is Bad
#Text=Beloved by many , avocados are delicious , nutritious and versatile .
#Text=However , knowing the right time to eat them can be tricky .
#Text=As well as the adverse health effects of eating food that has gone bad , an avocado that is just overripe may be safe to eat , but very unpleasant .
#Text=By knowing what to look out for and how to store avocados you can avoid disappointment .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Examining the Avocado
#Text=Look at the outer skin of the avocado .
#Text=If there is visible mould , or a rancid odour , the avocado is not safe to eat and should be discarded .
#Text=If the avocado is severely dented and marked , or has squashed areas it has likely gone bad .
#Text=Check the color .
#Text=Different varieties of avocado have different skin colours .
#Text=The most common variety of avocado , the Hass , will change colour to very dark green or purple colour when ripe .
#Text=If a Hass avocado has reached a deep black colour , it may be past its prime .
#Text=Most other commercially available avocados , like the Bacon , Fuerte , Gwen , Pinkerton , Reed and Zutano retain a green colour even when ripe .
#Text=Hold the avocado in your hand and apply gentle pressure .
#Text=Take care not to bruise the fruit with your fingertips .
#Text=A ripe avocado will yield slightly with light force .
#Text=If slight pressure leaves an indent in the avocado , it is a sign it has gone bad .
#Text=Using the stem of the avocado to check for ripeness .
#Text=Some people advocate checking for softness by pushing in or removing the stem .
#Text=If the stem moves easily it means the avocado is ripe .
#Text=Once the stem is removed the colour of the flesh is also revealed .
#Text=This method may be effective when judging softness but not when judging colour .
#Text=To get a good indication of the quality of the flesh more surface area needs to be seen .
#Text=If you are examining avocados to purchase , you should avoid tampering with the fruit in this way .
#Text=Removing the stem can compromise the quality of the fruit for other prospective purchasers .
#Text=Cut the avocado open .
#Text=If you already own the avocado , this is the quickest way to determine if it has gone bad .
#Text=The flesh should be a light green colour .
#Text=If the flesh is black or brown , the avocado should not be eaten .
#Text=If there is some minor bruising in the form of small , isolated areas of brown discolouration , the avocado is okay to eat .
#Text=Taste the avocado .
#Text=If you have thoroughly inspected the flesh but are not sure whether the avocado has gone bad , it is safe to perform a taste test .
#Text=Avoiding any brown spots , try a small amount of the green flesh .
#Text=Avocado should be creamy , mild and subtly sweet .
#Text=If it smells or tastes musky or off , it has gone bad .
#Text=Keeping Avocados Fresh
#Text=Avoid overripe avocados by storing them correctly .
#Text=If an avocado has achieved optimal ripeness but will not be eaten immediately , store it in the fridge .
#Text=An uncut , ripe avocado can last approximately 3-4 days at room temperature , or 7-10 days if refrigerated .
#Text=Store cut avocados to preserve freshness .
#Text=To store an avocado after it has been cut , cover tightly with plastic wrap and/or store it in an air tight container for up to 2 to 3 days .
#Text=To retain a light green colour for as long as possible , sprinkle a light layer of lemon juice on the cut flesh .
#Text=The slight acid content will help halt oxidation and prevent the flesh of the avocado from turning brown as quickly .
#Text=When avocado flesh has oxidised , it does not mean that the fruit is inedible .
#Text=Take a spoon or other utensil and gently scrape away the brown surface area .
#Text=The underlying avocado flesh should be light green .
#Text=Freeze avocado to avoid waste .
#Text=To prolong the life of an avocado
#Text=puree the flesh with lemon juice and keep in a sealed container .
#Text=The puree will keep for up to 4 months in the freezer .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Avocados continue to ripen after being harvested and can take up to 4 to 5 days to ripen when stored at room temperature .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Avocados produce ethylene , a gas that hastens the ripening of fruit .
#Text=Storing avocados in a confined space , or with other ethylene-producing fruits like bananas , peaches and apples will cause them to ripen quickly .
#Text=Quick Summary
